description:
Updated the example build system to enable complex socket permissions.

The PERMISSIONS field in example.dsc contains a list of permissions strings, as before. The new SOCKET_PERMISSIONS field contains a list of strings for the socket sub-permissions.

BUG=None
TEST=None
R=binji@chromium.org,bradnelson@google.com

Committed: https://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome?view=rev&revision=213994

messages.text: build_app.py works now, and it properly merges complex permissions, even if they take the form of dictionaries. My Python skills are rubbish, so I apologize if it's not very idiomatic!

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py
File native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode117
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:117: # recursively merge the dictionaries, combining inner lists.
this isn't recursive, but it looks like it is not necessary: http://developer.chrome.com/apps/declare_permissions.html

Only "socket" and "mediaGalleries" are dicts, and they always have lists of strings.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode117
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:117: # recursively merge the dictionaries, combining inner lists.
BTW, make a new function for this.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode118
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:118: for p1 in [p for p in permissions if isinstance(p, dict)]:
clearer to just iterate and continue:

for permission in permssions:
  if not isinstance(permission, dict):
    continue
  ...

EDIT: though in this case you want to handle the non-dict case too.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode119
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:119: # dictionaries contain exactly one item
If you depend on this, then assert

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode122
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:122: for p2 in [p for p in all_permissions if isinstance(p, dict)]:
why loop? just:

all_permissions.get(k)

and check that it is a dict

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode130
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:130: all_permissions.extend([p for p in permissions
why not just do this as part of the above loop:

for permission in permissions:
  if isinstance(permission, dict):
    # dict handling...
  else:
    # list handling...

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/examples/resources/manifest.json.template
File native_client_sdk/src/examples/resources/manifest.json.template (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/examples/resources/manifest.json.template#newcode22
native_client_sdk/src/examples/resources/manifest.json.template:22: "permissions":
Maybe simpler to just omit it entirely if it isn't defined.

Thanks for the feedback, I think this looks a little better.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py
File native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py (right):

On 2013/07/24 21:39:09, binji wrote:
> BTW, make a new function for this.

Done.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode117
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:117: # recursively merge the dictionaries, combining inner lists.
On 2013/07/24 21:39:09, binji wrote:
> this isn't recursive, but it looks like it is not necessary:
> http://developer.chrome.com/apps/declare_permissions.html
> 
> Only "socket" and "mediaGalleries" are dicts, and they always have lists of
> strings.

Whoops, the comment was based on an earlier version of the code. I obviously don't need to do a true recursive merge, but I do need to merge the lists inside the dicts.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode118
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:118: for p1 in [p for p in permissions if isinstance(p, dict)]:
On 2013/07/24 21:39:09, binji wrote:
> clearer to just iterate and continue:
> 
> for permission in permssions:
>   if not isinstance(permission, dict):
>     continue
>   ...
> 
> EDIT: though in this case you want to handle the non-dict case too.

Done.

On 2013/07/24 21:39:09, binji wrote:
> why loop? just:
> 
> all_permissions.get(k)
> 
> and check that it is a dict

I don't think this will work. I'm looking for a dict in all_permissions that contains k, not an element k in all_permissions that is a dict.

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/10001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode130
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:130: all_permissions.extend([p for p in permissions

> why not just do this as part of the above loop:
> 
> for permission in permissions:
>   if isinstance(permission, dict):
>     # dict handling...
>   else:
>     # list handling...

Done.

Ah, I see.

Perhaps we should use a separate file to how the manifest snippet rather than trying to quote json within a python dict?

https://codereview.chromium.org/19601010/diff/28001/native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc
File native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc (right):

https://codereview.chromium.org/19601010/diff/28001/native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc#newcode19
native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc:19: ]"""
This syntax is pretty horrible.

Is there nothing nicer we can do here?

https://codereview.chromium.org/19601010/diff/28001/native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc
File native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc (right):

https://codereview.chromium.org/19601010/diff/28001/native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc#newcode19
native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc:19: ]"""
On 2013/07/25 17:29:06, Sam Clegg wrote:
> This syntax is pretty horrible.
> 
> Is there nothing nicer we can do here?

Well, another option is to have "PERMISSIONS" and "SOCKET_PERMISSIONS" And have the manifest template sort it out.

AFAICT, sockets and mediaGalleries are the only permissions that require dicts with lists, and we don't currently use mediaGalleries.

On 2013/07/25 17:32:23, binji wrote:
> https://codereview.chromium.org/19601010/diff/28001/native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc
> File native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc (right):
> 
> https://codereview.chromium.org/19601010/diff/28001/native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc#newcode19
> native_client_sdk/src/examples/api/mouse_lock/example.dsc:19: ]"""
> On 2013/07/25 17:29:06, Sam Clegg wrote:
> > This syntax is pretty horrible.
> > 
> > Is there nothing nicer we can do here?
> 
> Well, another option is to have "PERMISSIONS" and "SOCKET_PERMISSIONS" And have
> the manifest template sort it out.
> 
> AFAICT, sockets and mediaGalleries are the only permissions that require dicts
> with lists, and we don't currently use mediaGalleries.

So, I've implemented Ben's idea, and it's definitely much cleaner, and now you don't have to change the existing example.dsc files. I also made the manifest.json template cleaner, by using json.dumps to format the permissions list, rather than doing it manually in the template.

this looks much better. Thanks for complaining, Sam. :D

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/41001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py
File native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py (right):

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/41001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode115
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:115: if not isinstance(x, dict)]
shouldn't be possible for x to be a dict anymore, correct? So this can become:

permissions = project.get('PERMISSIONS', [])

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/41001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode120
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:120: if len(all_socket_permissions) > 0:
if all_socket_permissions:

is more pythonic

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/41001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py#newcode121
native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:121: socket_dict = dict([('socket', all_socket_permissions)])
socket_dict = {'socket': all_socket_permissions}

better yet, just fold that into the append below

native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:124: indent=4, separators=(',', ': '))
these are the default separators, so you can remove it

if socket_permissions:

https://chromiumcodereview.appspot.com/19601010/diff/41001/native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py

native_client_sdk/src/build_tools/build_app.py:115: if not isinstance(x, dict)]
Hmm, I did this because I was mysteriously finding dicts in permissions. Turns out it was because I was mutating the permissions list in generate_make.py, it's fixed now.
